title: Support to the National Malaria Control Programme
description: Malaria is the principal cause of sickness and death in Angola.  The disease accounts for 25 percent of recorded illness in all age groups.  The annual number of deaths recorded due to malaria is approximately 11,000, of which 35 percent are children under the age of five.   The program supported by this grant aims to reduce illness and death from malaria by at least 25 percent by improving access to and the effective use of malaria treatment for children under five, pregnant women and the general population most at risk of infection.  More specifically, grant monies are being used to improve access to and use of artemisinin-based combination therapy; improve access to and use of intermittent preventive treatment for pregnant women; and increase access and effective use of insecticide-treated bed nets by families with children under the age of five and pregnant women..

title: Support to the National Tuberculosis Control Program
description: TB is a major public health problem in Angola.  Although the country established a national program for the control of TB in 1981, nearly three decades of civil war have displaced 35 percent of the population, destroyed 70 percent of the country’s health facilities, and left a substantial proportion of the population vulnerable to the disease. The program supported by this grant will extend Directly-Observed Treatment, short course (DOTS) services to 68 municipalities in 11 provinces which do not currently have them, ensuring that there is at least one DOTS facility in each municipality.  After laying a strong foundation for DOTS, the program will work to prevent circumstances that challenge DOTS expansion, such resistance to TB drugs and HIV/TB co-infection.   The expected impact of the program is an increase in both case detection and treatment success, with a subsequent reduction in TB transmission, illness and fatality....

title: Reducing the Burden of HIV/AIDS in Angola
description: Angola's large number of internally displaced persons, together with increased contact with military personnel, low levels of education, a young population and destroyed social networks, have made it a fertile breeding ground for the spread of HIV. The principal goal of the program supported by this grant is to prevent HIV transmission and reduce the socio-economic impact of the HIV epidemic in Angola.  The program aims to achieve its goals through the implementation an integrated approach targeted at multiple sectors that reinforces and extends existing efforts in HIV prevention, treatment and surveillance while increasing institutional capacity, mobilizing and supporting people living with HIV and AIDS, coordinating partners and monitoring the distribution and use of resources.

title: Scaling Up Malaria Interventions in Angola
description: Malaria remains the major public health problem in Angola and is reported to be the principal cause of sickness and death in the country.  As a result of conflict, Angola's malaria control activities were significantly constrained for many years.  The program supported by this grant builds on activities undertaken in the first phase of a program that received Global Fund financing in Round 3 and aims to achieve a 60 percent reduction of the impact of malaria in Angola by 2012.  Targeting the two most vulnerable groups to malaria – children under five years of age and pregnant women – the program will use grant monies to procure and distribute long-lasting insecticide-treated bed nets free of charge to families in need; increase access to artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) treatment; and disseminate information on malaria prevention and treatment.

title: Expanding and improving Diagnostic and Treatment Services for Tuberculosis in Angola
description: Tuberculosis (TB) remains a major public health problem in Angola. According to World Health Organization’s (WHO) Global TB Control Report 2009, the number of new sputum smear positive cases notified increased almost threefold, from approximately 7,379 to more than 21,422 between 1999 and 2007. WHO estimates that there are 48,777 new TB cases and between 2002 and 2007, Directly Observed Treatment Short-course (DOTS) coverage increased from 43 to 63 percent. The National Strategic Plan from 2008 to 2012 aims at extending DOTS network to the entire country and expanding the coverage of laboratories and caring for TB/HIV patients. The program will target vulnerable population in urban and rural communities in 18 provinces of Angola and HIV positive patients. The activities of the program will include creating new service points for DOTS, providing equipment and material to existing laboratories, producing and disseminating information education, and communication materials to TB and TB/HIV patients, providing quality supervision to laboratories, provincial and municipal facilities, and training staff involved in program implementation at the national, provincial, municipal and health facilities level.

title: Strengthening Albania's National Response to HIV/AIDS Among Vulnterable Groups
description: Albania has a low prevalence of HIV and AIDS. However, data show an upward trend of new diagnoses and suggest a larger number of undiagnosed cases. As of June 2008, the National HIV/AIDS Program reported a total of 324 HIV infections, with 48 new cases midway through the year. The Institute of Public Health implements Albania’s response to HIV and AIDS under a national strategy for the period 2004 to 2010. The program supported by this Round 5 grant aims to maintain low HIV prevalence among all vulnerable groups in Albania – including Roma,female sex workers, men who have sex with men and injecting drug users – and to provide care, support and treatment for people living with HIV and AIDS. The program focuses on harm reduction, drug substitution treatment and HIV and AIDS education for injecting drug users in prisons.

title: Scaling-up the National Response to Tuberculosis
description: Thanks to the successful implementation of its Round 5 TB grant, Albania has seen new TB cases decline steadily since 2004. Only 425 TB cases (with 159 new smear-positive cases) were reported for the 12 month period ending 31March 2009. The country currently reports a low TB incidence of 13.5 new cases per 100,000 inhabitants (with 5.9/100,000 new smear-positive cases), a low treatment default rate and a low death rate from the disease. The Ministry of Health reports a treatment success rate exceeding  90 percent. The aim of the program supported by this grant, implemented by the Ministry’s Institute of Public Health, is to reduce the disease burden to such an extent that TB no longer constitutes a public health problem. In order to achieve this goal, active case finding is being strengthened to ensure that vulnerable groups – including ethnic groups such as Roma, prisoners, immigrant workers and unemployed youth – have access to TB diagnosis and treatment, that drug resistance is avoided, that TB/HIV co-infection is prevented, and that the National TB Control Program is rationally integrated into the primary health care system.

title: Closing gaps to universal access
description: HIV infection in Argentina is mostly concentrated in most at-risk populations (MARPs) such as gay men and other men who have sex with men (MSM), transgender people, sex workers (SWs) and injecting drug users (IDUs).  The Program focuses on these groups, supporting and strengthening the national response to the epidemic. The program aims to strengthen preventive activities aimed at MARPs; to produce quality data and studies about most at-risk groups; to support the most at-risk populations living with HIV (including partners and/or family members) and to improve the health care services. The goal of this Program is to reduce the HIV incidence among gay men and other MSM, transgender people, SWs and IDUs; to reduce stigma and discrimination because of sexual orientation, gender identity and HIV; and to promote universal access to integral health care and better quality of life for gay men and other MSM, transgender people, IDUs and SWs living with HIV, their partners and family members.

title: Support Activities for the Prevention and Control of HIV/AIDS in Argentina
description: In Argentina, HIV and AIDS is concentrated among vulnerable populations. Sexual transmission and poor education are the drivers of the epidemic in this country. The program supported by this grant, implemented by the United Nations Development Programme, aims to expand HIV and AIDS prevention activities across the nation. The program seeks to reduce the incidence of HIV among the general population as well as within vulnerable groups, to improve the quality of life for people living with HIV and to improve the operational capacity of health system authorities engaged in the field of HIV and AIDS prevention and treatment. A prevention campaign geared towards vulnerable populations – including teenagers, women and the poor – has been established. Funded activities focus on strengthening civil society institutions for the prevention of mother-to-child transmission, TB co-infection, and to foster treatment adherence.

title: Support Activities for the Prevention and Control of HIV/AIDS
description: In Argentina, HIV and AIDS is concentrated among vulnerable populations. Sexual transmission and poor education are the drivers of the epidemic in this country. The program supported by this grant aims to expand HIV and AIDS prevention activities across the nation. The program seeks to reduce the incidence of HIV among the general population as well as within vulnerable groups, to improve the quality of life for people living with HIV and to improve the operational capacity of health system authorities engaged in the field of HIV and AIDS prevention and treatment. A prevention campaign geared towards vulnerable populations – including teenagers, women and the poor – has been established. Funded activities also focus on strengthening civil society institutions for the prevention of mother-to-child transmission of HIV and TB co-infection, and to foster treatment adherence. This grant constitutes Phase 2 of the ARG-102-G01-H-00 grant and built on the activities implemented.

title: Support to the National Programme on HIV/AIDS Prevention
description: While Armenia’s HIV epidemic is still concentrated among at-risk groups, it is growing. The main modes of HIV transmission are heterosexual contact and injecting drug use. The program conducted awareness-raising campaigns to educate the general population and youth about the disease and ways of preventing it. It also carried out prevention activities targeted at vulnerable groups, such as injecting drug users, sex workers, men who have sex with men, prisoners, migrants and refugees. In addition, grant monies were used to prevent mother-to-child transmission of HIV, to create access to voluntary counseling and testing and diagnostic services, as well as to treatment with antiretroviral drugs for those who need it. The program was also tasked with ensuring the safety of the donated blood supply and the training of specialists. One of the program’s achievements was strengthening of the operational capacity of institutions dedicated to the prevention and treatment of HIV and AIDS. The implementation of the program finished on 30 September 2009 and is continued by the Rolling Continuation Channel HIV grants implemented by two Principal Recipients – the Ministry of Health and Mission East.

title: Support to the National Program on the Response to HIV Epicemic in the Republic of Armenia
description: While Armenia is still a country with a concentrated HIV epidemic, it has seen a substantial growth of identified HIV cases over the past six years, partially due to increased voluntary counseling and testing services. This program implemented by the Ministry of Health aims to accelerate the reduction of the HIV epidemic in the country by providing antiretroviral treatment for those who need it, universal access to counseling and testing among pregnant women and general population, HIV prevention activities among prisoners and mobile populations, methadone substitution treatment, HIV education in school settings, strengthening of national information, monitoring and evaluation, laboratory and procurement and supply management systems.

title: Support to the National Program on the Response to HIV Epicemic in the Republic of Armenia (Program)
description: While Armenia is still a country with a concentrated HIV epidemic, it has seen a substantial growth of identified HIV cases over the past six years, partially due to increased voluntary counseling and testing services. This program implemented by Mission East aims to improve access to counseling and testing among most-at-risk populations, HIV prevention activities among injecting drug users, sex workers, men who have sex with men, most-at-risk adolescents aged 15-17; peer education among youth (15-24 years old); care and support to adults and children living with and affected by HIV; and institutional capacity building of civil society organizations.

title: Strengthening of the National TB Control Programme in the Republic of Armenia
description: TB re-emerged as an important public health problem in Armenia in the 1990s. Armenia adopted DOTS as a national strategy in 1995. Although coverage is considered to be 100 percent, implementation is compromised by organizational weaknesses. The program this grant supports focuses on decentralizing TB case detection and ambulatory treatment through the involvement of the primary health care sector. TB treatment will be administered closer to patient residences, and a treatment adherence strategy will be established, consisting mainly of regular health education and social support for TB patients. The overall goal of the program is to reduce the burden of TB in Armenia by providing increased access to TB diagnostic and treatment services for the country's poor and vulnerable population groups as well as improving the quality of these services. In particular, it targets people with immunodeficiency syndrome, including HIV-positive individuals and introduces TB/HIV collaborative activities which have not been addressed by the ongoing HIV and AIDS programs.

title: Scaling up the management of drug-resistant tuberculosis in the Republic of Armenia
description: TB re-emerged as an important public health problem in Armenia in the 1990s. Armenia adopted DOTS as a national strategy in 1995. Although coverage is considered to be 100 percent, the country lags far behind the target in terms of treatment outcomes. One of the most important reasons for this is the high burden of drug resistance. The program aims to improve the treatment success rate by expanding multidrug-resistant TB diagnosis and treatment services. The program focuses on decentralizing TB case detection and ambulatory treatment through the involvement of the primary health care sector. It targets homeless people, prisoners and ex-prisoners, refugees and people with immunodeficiency syndrome. The overall goal of the program is to reduce the burden of TB in Armenia through increasing access to and the quality of TB diagnostic and treatment services.

title: Scaling up HIV Prevention, Treatment, Care and Support in Armenia
description: Being one of the post-Soviet countries, Armenia inherited many of the problems intrinsic to the health systems in the region. The country is engaged in reforming its health care system towards a primary care orientation and community approach. With this grant, Armenia became the first country in the region to receive direct assistance to improve its health system. The country aims to use the funding to strengthen and develop its health sector workforce, integrate palliative care into the national health system and implement a national blood safety strategy. The program supported by this grant seeks to revise the curricula of medical personnel in accordance with the current needs and standards and to incorporate modern approaches to TB and HIV/AIDS diagnostics, treatment, and management. Among other objectives, the program is tasked with capacity-building in procurement and supply of medicines and commodities for addressing priority diseases.

title: Strengthening the National TB Control Program to scale up the management of drug-resistant TB in the Republic of Armenia
description: Tuberculosis (TB) re-emerged as an important public health problem after Armenia gained its independence from the Soviet Union in 1991, and the burden of the disease remains high. Resistance to anti-TB drugs represents a serious obstacle to effective control of the TB epidemic in Armenia. The Program has two main objectives: to strengthen the National TB Control Program to provide better diagnostics and treatment, including the scale-up of the management of drug-resistant TB (DR-TB) in the country by enrolling over a thousand multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB) patients over five years from the civilian and penitentiary sectors, and to improve the supportive environment for effective TB control. It aims to strengthen the National TB Control Program in the following areas: procurement and supply management, human resources, MDR-TB and TB diagnostics and case management, social support to TB patients, TB/HIV co-infection, infection control, monitoring and evaluation, advocacy, communication and social mobilization. Its goals are to reduce TB incidence & mortality and prevent the further development of drug-resistant TB by targeting all TB and DR-TB patients. This is a consolidation of Round 10 and Round 8 TB grants.

title: Scaling-up the Reponse to HIV/AIDS in Azerbaijan
description: In Azerbaijan, HIV remains concentrated in groups considered most at risk of infection: injecting drug users, female sex workers, men who have sex with men, prisoners, migrants and vulnerable youth, but the epidemic continues to spread. Round 4 grant is financing major components of Azerbaijan's National AIDS Strategy, including antiretroviral therapy for people living with AIDS, scale up of HIV/AIDS and sexually transmitted infection (STI) prevention programs among injecting drug users, female sex workers, men who have sex with men, and prisoners. Other key elements of the program are strengthening knowledge and awareness among vulnerable groups, reducing the stigma and discrimination associated with HIV, and strengthening the institutional capacity of Azerbaijan to better respond to HIV and other STIs by using a multisectoral approach. One of the strong components of the program is the implementation of life-skill based HIV and AIDS education for young people in almost 62.5 percent of primary and secondary schools in Azerbaijan. The Round 9 HIV grant is planned to continue activities under the Round 4 grant which ended in December 2009.

title: Strengthening and Expanding DOTS Framework by Improving Management and Coordination of the National TB Control Programme, Involving Primary Health Care in TB Control, Managing Drug Resistance and Reducing the Burden of TB in Vulnerable Population Gro
description: Azerbaijan faces a high TB burden and is among the 25 countries identified by the World Health Organization as top priority states in the fight against multidrug-resistant and extremely drug-resistant TB worldwide. As elsewhere in Eastern Europe and Central Asia, the country’s health services suffered in the years following the collapse of the Soviet Union. TB drugs were in short supply and nonstandard, incomplete treatment regimes were used, which helped fuel the development of drug-resistant strains of TB. The program supported by the Round 5 grant aimed to improve detection and diagnosis of TB cases, ensure quality treatment, manage the spread of drug-resistant TB by implementation of DOTS strategy and decrease the burden of TB among at-risk groups (people living with HIV, prisoners, labor migrants, refugees and internally displaced persons). The program contributed to building national capacities for effective TB control and strengthening management and coordination of the National Tuberculosis Control Program. Phase 2 of this grant was consolidated with the Round 7 TB grant for Azerbaijan.

title: Strenghening and Expanding the DOTS Framework and Scaling up the Management of Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis in the Republic of Azerbaijan
description:
A drug-resistant survey, conducted in 2007, showed multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB) prevalence of 22 percent among new TB cases and 56 percent among previously treated cases. Over 14 percent of all MDR-TB cases are extremely drug-resistant TB (XDR-TB). Azerbaijan is among the 25 priority MDR-TB and XDR-TB countries identified by the World Health Organization based on estimated MDR-TB burden (more than 10 percent among both new and retreatment cases combined).
 
The consoidated program encompasses the activities financed under Phase 2 of the Round 5 TB grant and the Round 7 TB grant. The program aims to reduce the burden of TB in Azerbaijan in high-risk population groups (including people living with HIV), prisoners, labor migrants, refugees and internally displaced persons) by strengthening and expanding the DOTS framework, scaling up the management of drug-resistant TB and preventing the further spread of drug-resistant TB including XDR-TB. This consoidated program also aims to improving the detection, diagnosis and quality treatment of TB cases (including MDR-TB) and contributing to the universal access of the population to diagnosis and treatment. These objectives are achieved by strengthening the management and coordination of the National TB Control Program, involving the primary health care network in TB control, introducing and scaling up drug-resistant TB management, sustaining drug resistance surveillance throughout the country, strengthening DOTS in penitentiaries and upgrading the laboratory services.

title: Undertaing a new effort towards the sustainable malaria control and prevention
description: The malaria situation in Azerbaijan deteriorated rapidly after 1990 due to dramatic worsening of socioeconomic conditions and a nearly complete cessation of preventive activities. In addition, malaria control efforts in the southwestern part of the country were complicated by high mobility of the population and the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict. New malaria cases hit a peak of 13,135 in 1996. This prompted the government to develop the National Malaria Control Program in 1998 in cooperation with World Health Organization (WHO) Regional Office for Europe. By 2006 Azerbaijan’s malaria situation had improved dramatically, with only 143 new cases reported. Although the incidence is now relatively low - less than one infection per 1,000 people – the threat of renewed outbreaks remains high: 80 percent of the country is considered to be prone to malaria transmission and active foci are reported in many districts. The overall goal of the program the Round 7 grant supports is to reduce the transmission and incidence of P. vivax malaria and to prevent malaria outbreaks. The program is based on the National Malaria Elimination Strategy for the period 2008–2013 and aims to achieve its goals by training health staff in malaria-related planning, epidemic preparedness and monitoring, in line with the WHO's technical guidelines on malaria control and prevention, update existing legislation and regulations on malaria control, upgrade the country's laboratories in order to improve diagnosis of malaria cases and strengthen national capacities for timely response and prevention of malaria outbreaks.

title: Streamlining the Response to HIV/AIDS  Epidemic in Azerbaijan by Strengthening National Capacities and Scaling up Prevention and Treatment with Emphasis on the Most at Risk Population Groups and Civil Society Participation
description: Azerbaijan is a lower-middle income country with a concentrated HIV epidemic. HIV prevalence in adults is estimated at 0.2 percent (UNAIDS, 2008 Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic). Although the national burden of HIV appears comparatively low, it is probably underestimated - due, in particular, to difficulties in accessing most-at-risk population groups. The predominant HIV transmission mode is sharing of injecting equipment among people who inject drugs. The government of Azerbaijan is committed to fighting the HIV epidemic and allocates increasing amounts of financial, human and infrastructural resources for this purpose, particularly to cover the substantial costs of staff, medical interventions and facility expenses. However, substantial financial and programmatic gaps exist, especially with regards to the complex and costly interventions in HIV prevention and treatment activities among most-at-risk population groups. The program supported by this grant aims to ensure the continuation and scaling-up of the activities initiated under the Round 4-supported program, which ended in June 2010. This program will initiate new activities, such as expansion of voluntary counseling and testing, ensuring universal access to prevention of mother-to-child transmission of HIV and establishing community-based care and support.

title: Strengthening TB control in Penitentiary System of Azerbaijan
description: Azerbaijan faces a high Tuberculosis (TB) burden and is among the 25 countries identified by the World Health Organization as top priority states in fighting against multidrug-resistant (MDR) and extremely drug-resistant TB worldwide.  In 2008, TB’s prevalence in prisons exceeded the country wide level over 40 times.  The program aims on strengthening essential Directly Observed Treatment Short-term (DOTS) interventions as the key requirement for preventing resistance, as well as in achieving and sustaining universal access of the prison population to quality and timely diagnosis and treatment of drug-resistant forms of the disease.  The program focuses on TB and MDR-TB patients in the penitentiary sector.  The current grant complements the existing Round 7 TB grant in Azerbaijan implemented by the Ministry of Health, with the Ministry of Justice as sub-recipient for activities in the penitentiary sector.   The program plans to provide training and re-training for TB doctors, nurses and laboratory technicians working in the penitentiary system, establish a proper supervision of TB control interventions in prisons, and upgrade the central laboratory of the Specialized Treatment for Detainees with TB (STID) with relevant equipment and supplies for rapid diagnosis of drug-resistant form of the disease.

title: Support to the Initiative "Faire Reculer Le Plaudisme" or "Roll Back Malaria" in Burundi
description: Malaria is the prime cause of morbidity and mortality in Burundi. Between 1991 and 2000 the country experienced an unprecedented malaria epidemic with over a threefold increase in the number of malaria cases. The program supported by this grant will expand the implementation of existing malaria control activities, including antivectorial strategies and epidemiological surveillance systems.  The objective of the program, which is aimed at pregnant women, children under five and non-immune populations from the high plateau region, is to reduce the illness rate linked to malaria in health units by 50 percent. The Round 2 Program contributed to the reversal of the gradual upward trend of malaria cases seen in Burundi every year. Prevalence of malaria went from 46% in 2000 down to 29% in 2006.

title: Strengthening the National Programme to Fight Tuberculosis
description: The Program focuses on strengthening the National Programme to fight Tuberculosis (TB).   Intervention will be through reinforcing the application of the Directly Observed Therapy Short Course (DOTS) strategy. Prevailing adverse conditions within Burundi including civil war, population movements and the high incidence of HIV/AIDS have contributed to the considerable increase in the number of reported TB cases.   The Program will work in close collaboration with HIV/AIDS program to reduce morbidity and mortality due to the two diseases.

title: Supporting the reach of global coverage in LLITNs for sustainable prevention of Malaria in Burundi
description: Malaria is imposing a constantly increasing burden and is the primary cause of illness and death in Burundi. Half the population is at risk of infection. The program supported by this grant aims to scale up the mass campaign to provide universal coverage with long-lasting insecticidal nets (LLINs) to the remaining eight uncovered provinces to protect the entire Burundian population. In addition, the program will renew the mass LLIN campaign to all 17 provinces in 2013. The expected outcomes by 2015 are 100 percent household coverage and at least 80 percent LLIN use among the general population.

title: Support to Consolidate Key Interventions to Control Malaria in Burundi
description: This grant is the consolidation of the grant BRN-202-G05-M which finances mainly malaria case management activities, including procurement of health commodities, and of the grant BRN-910-G09-M which has financed the LLINs mass campaign of June 2014 and supports supervision of community-based activities. The consolidated grant will finance case management activities, including diagnostics and treatment, through procurement of pharmaceutical and health products, in coordination with the President Malaria Initiative; in particular, it supports the implementation of the new malaria Standard Treatment Guidelines, specifically the introduction of Intermittent Preventive Treatment and use of Artesunate Injectable to treat sever malaria. The grant also finances Monitoring & Evaluations activities, including funding for the 2015 Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) with parasitemia testing, data quality meetings and a biannual drug efficacy study. It also supports the National Malaria control Program.

title: Development Policy Credit 2: Fiscal Sustainability&Investment Climate
description: The development objectives of the Second Fiscal Sustainability and Investment Climate Development Policy Credit Project for Bhutan are to promote fiscal discipline, improve access to finance for enterprises, and improve the climate for business entry and investment in Bhutan. The programmatic series has three pillars: (i) strengthening fiscal sustainability and self-reliance; (ii) increasing access to finance; and (iii) improving the investment climate and increasing domestic and foreign investment. To realize rapid economic growth, the Royal Government of Bhutan (RGoB) continues to focus on five economic jewels: hydropower, agriculture, tourism, cottage and small industries, and mining. Implementation of the development management system has supported poverty reduction and gender equality. To sustain these achievements, two key economic challenges must be addressed: sustaining macroeconomic stability and boosting private-sector development. The high current account deficits are the result of elevated imports associated with the construction of hydropower projects, which are covered by long-term donor financing. Private-sector-led economic development will depend on further improving the investment climate.

This stellar growth performance has helped improve living standards and has contributed to poverty reduction. However, further welfare improvements will require a dynamic job-creating private sector. The current hydropower driven growth model has created some macroeconomic imbalances and coupled with a large and dominant public sector, impeded the development of a vibrant private sector. As a result, the economy has witnessed considerable volatility, and limited job creation. This DPC series will help the government address some of these challenges by supporting reforms aimed at improving the management of macroeconomic volatility, strengthening domestic resource mobilization, and promoting employment opportunities in the private sector. The DPC series is also consistent with Bhutan's 11th (2013-18) and 12th Five-Year Plans (FYP) (2018-23). The proposed operations are structured around two pillars. title: DR Congo Private Sector Development and Competitiveness Project
description: The objective of the Private Sector Development and Competitiveness Project for Democratic Republic Congo (DRC) is to support the Borrower's policy of the promotion of private-sector led growth through: (a) improving the investment climate; (b) supporting parastatal reform in the telecommunications, energy, finance, transport, and mining sectors; and (c) improving mining competitiveness in the Katanga region of the Borrower. This restructuring paper seeks your approval to proceed with the extension of the Project closing date by 6 months, from December 31, 2012 to June 30, 2013. The 6 month extension was approved in principle by Regional Vice President (RVP) on October 17, 2012, conditional upon fulfillment of prior actions which have now been satisfied, enabling the transfer of certain activities of high corporate reputation risk to other Bank projects for continuation and completion of their implementation. These include (i) an activity of the Management Action Plan (MAP) approved by the Board in May 2011 in response to an Inspection Panel request on behalf of ex-workers of the mining enterprise Gecamines who took part in a Project-supported labor retrenchment program in 2004-5, and (ii) a critical phase of the National Payments System (NPS) implementation at the Central Bank of Congo (BCC). The extension of closing date would allow the Project to make up for the time lost due to disruptions caused by election related political instability from mid-2011 to January 2012, including a period of one and a half months when the Country Office was closed and all staff evacuated. This is the second extension of the Project, pushing its cumulative extension to 39 months and age to 9 years and 11 months at closing.

title: DRC Education Sector Project
description: The objective of the Education Sector Project for Congo, Democratic Republic of is to prevent further deterioration in the delivery of essential services for primary education and prepare ground for a sustainable development and financing of the sector that will facilitate donor coordination and future transition to a sector wide program. The restructuring is a level two restructuring. One of the strengths of the project, as indicated in the findings of the recent Quality Assessment of Lending Portfolio (QALP), lies with a 'relevant and appropriate DO that reflects the strategic focus of the project'.  The restructuring will be undertaken to refine the scope of the project in order to improve project performance towards its development objectives. The components and subcomponents will remain but the restructuring will narrow the range of activities that are included in some subcomponents. Using the positive developments in the sector, alternative measures will be proposed in order to facilitate the financing of teachers' salaries and the schools' operating costs. In addition, the restructuring will introduce, on a relatively modest basis, the community participatory factor in the school rehabilitation program. This factor stems from the school construction strategy that was recently developed by the Government with project's technical support. Finally, the restructuring proposes a one year extension of the project closing date from December 31, 2012 to December 31, 2013 to help complete the execution of some core activities.

The second component is the build sector management capacity. The third component is the enhance transparency and accountability. To assist the Government in capturing taxes from the mining sector, the project will help to streamline and reinforce government tax administration departments and strengthen tax collection and revenues. title: DRC Street Children Project
description: The objective of the Street Children Project for Congo, Democratic Republic of is to improve the delivery mechanisms of prevention and support services for street children, primarily in Kinshasa. There are three components to the project, the first component being prevention. The project will also finance efforts to keep children in school, liaising with the Ministry of Education to ensure coordination and an efficient use of available resources (including the International Development Association (IDA)-financed education project). As experience shows that dropping out of school is often the first step toward life in the streets, many local actors support school attendance for at-risk children as a preventive measure. The second component is the assistance. This component will finance a set of activities aimed at improving coverage and quality of services for street children, with special attention to street girls. Finally, the third component is the capacity building, coordination, and project management. This component will provide for technical assistance and training to strengthen Ministry of Social Affairs, Humanitarian Action and National Solidarity (MINAS') capacity to: (i) develop standards for activities targeting street children; (ii) coordinate the interventions of different stakeholders; and (iii) monitor and evaluate ongoing interventions. When relevant, capacity building will also include staff of other ministries (e.g., Ministry of Justice, Ministry of Gender, Family and Children).

title: DR CONGO - Quality and Relevance of Secondary and Tertiary Education Project
description: The development objectives of the Quality and Relevance of Secondary and Tertiary Education Project for Democratic Republic of Congo are to: (i) improve the teaching and learning of mathematics and science in general secondary education, and (ii) enhance relevance of technical and vocational education and training (TVET) in priority sectors at secondary and tertiary levels. The project comprises of three components. The first component, improve the teaching and learning of mathematics and science in general secondary education supports the strategic direction of improving the quality of secondary education expansion and the provision of a more suitable environment for teaching and learning of Math and Science. It consists of following two sub-components: (i) development of secondary education strategic framework and strengthening of mathematics and science curricula for secondary education with improved teaching and learning conditions; and (ii) upgrading mathematics and science curricula for in-service and pre-service training of secondary teachers at higher teacher training institute (ISPs). The second component, enhance the relevance of TVET in priority sectors at secondary and tertiary education levels uses a two-pronged approach to improve knowledge and skills in priority sectors to support accelerated economic growth; and to better align the delivery of TVET with labor market demand. It consists of following three sub-components: (i) development of a TVET strategy and enabling framework; (ii) enhancing the quality and relevance of secondary TVET in the priority sectors; and (iii) enhancing the quality and relevance of tertiary TVET in the priority sectors. The third component, project coordination, monitoring and evaluation supports activities aiming to ensure effective project execution and coordination, and monitoring and evaluation of project outcomes.

title: DRC-Statistics Development Project
description: The development objective of the Statistics Development Project for Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) is to strengthen the capacity of the national statistical system (NSS) to produce and disseminate core economic and social statistics. The project comprises of two components. The first component, data production, dissemination, and use to strengthen the statistical infrastructure for poverty and economic monitoring will finance the implementation of a program of activities designed to improve the statistical infrastructure, and the quality and timeliness of national accounts statistics, agriculture statistics, and poverty and inequality statistics produced by the NSS. It consists of following five sub-components: (i) support to the cartography of the population and housing census; (ii) system of surveys on household living conditions: poverty, inequality, and jobs; (iii) agriculture census and surveys; (iv) national accounts statistics; and (v) improving information technology (IT) and equipment for data production and diffusion. The second component, human resources development and management aims at identifying and providing support to create an enabling environment for the DRC's NSS to produce and disseminate reliable statistics. It consists of following five sub-components: (i) staffing and policies; (ii) support for the development of the national statistics schools; (iii) scholarship program for the training of Congolese in the regional and national statistics and demography schools; (iv) young professionals program; and (v) project management.

title: DRC Reinsertion and Reintegration Project
description: The objective of the Reinsertion and Reintegration Project for Congo, Democratic Republic of is to support the socio-economic reintegration of demobilized ex-combatants. There are five components to the project, the first component being reinsertion. Reinsertion activities will follow disarmament and demobilization and will be provided for all demobilized ex-combatants at the Reintegration Preparation Centers (RPCs) over a six-month period to allow sufficient time for the various trainings. The second component is the Reintegration. The reintegration period will encompass two years after the ex-combatants return to their communities. This will be supported by the ongoing sensitization activities detailed in component. The third component is the support to demobilized ex-combatants households. The project will assist households of ex-combatants via primary support to the spouse and some additional support to other household members. In the aftermath of conflict and displacement, families are not necessarily cohesive, functional units, and frequently lack the resources, capacity, and skills to manage the re-establishment of their own lives, much less to accommodate the special needs and demands to assist returning ex-combatants to reintegrate socially and economically. The fourth component is the support to vulnerable groups. Follow-up monitoring and psycho-social support will be provided to those who are still in need when returning to their communities. In addition, referral options will be explored, including linkages with other projects in the areas of return. This community-based support will be contingent on existing capacity for the provision of such support which will be determined through an assessment of capacity. Finally, the fifth component is the project management, sensitization, monitoring and evaluation.

title: DRC - Goma Airport Safety Improvement Project
description: The project development objective for the Goma Airport Safety Improvement Project for the Congo is to improve the safety, security, and operations of Goma International Airport. The project consists of two components made up of a number of specific areas of work. Component A (Airport infrastructure investments) includes investments necessary to urgently enable the airport to meet international safety and security standards, and to bring its capacity to the level prior to the volcanic eruption. In summary this component will: rehabilitate the existing runway which was damaged by volcanic activity, and extension of the existing apron, rehabilitation of the airports electrical system, installation of new mobile control tower, upgrade air navigation aids, construction of airport security fence, support to air rescue and firefighting services, and rehabilitation of existing passenger terminal. Component B (Capacity Building and Project Implementation Support) includes activities necessary to support the institutional development of Goma airport, share lessons learned with other key airports in DRC, mitigate the risks associated with the volcanic activities in the area, promote interventions to provide social dividends to surrounding communities in this conflict-affected area, and ensure appropriate project implementation. The component will include the following activities: preparation of a priority airport rehabilitation program, monitoring of volcano risks and strengthening the preparedness of the airport and surrounding communities, provision of technical assistance to strengthen the economic and social fabric of the communities around the airport, and project implementation support.

title: Republic of Congo Support to Basic Education Project
description: The objective of the Support to Basic Education Project for Congo, Republic of is to improve efficiency, quality and equity in the provision of basic education in the territory of the Recipient with a view to achieving universal quality primary education by 2015. Since July 2011, Ministry of Primary and Secondary Education in charge of Literacy (MEPSA) has taken a number of actions that will create a stronger enabling environment for the project to proceed, notably: (i) the strengthening of the procurement capacity and the recruitment of an internal auditor, (ii) retrofitting the sector indicators with a consistent base of population projection, (iii) decision to continue with the United Nations Development Program (UNDP) for the execution of the 2nd phase of the school infrastructure and school-based management program, and (iv) partnership with Program on the Analysis of Education Systems (PASEC) for learning assessment. In addition MEPSA has prepared an implementation plan acceptable to the Bank to complete the project. The extension is the first and last extension of the additional financing to the original project. title: CG Rep. Agricultural Development and Rural Roads Rehabilitation Proj.
description: The objective of the Agricultural Development and Rural Roads Rehabilitation Project for Congo is to increase the ability of the rural poor to raise their income through the generation and promotion of improved agricultural technologies, the provision of market infrastructure, and the formulation and implementation of poverty-focused agricultural policies and expenditure programs. This paper pertains to the provision of an additional credit for the project. The aims of this additional financing are to help finance the costs associated with scaling up of the project's activities, to devote a concerted effort to focus interventions in specific high potential agricultural areas, and to capitalize on the achievements of the parent project and increase synergy between the components in order to achieve more development impact on the ground. The additional financing will also be used to introduce a value chain approach for a few carefully selected agricultural commodities and to ensure that micro-projects that are being financed follow the logic of developing these value chains. Other changes suggested herein include changes to the results framework, a change in the safeguard policy, and change to the disbursement estimates and costs. These changes are in accordance with the provision of the credit, in order to effectively utilize the additional financing.
